Here's a multi-form question based on the documentation:

Question: When using biblatex, which method allows you to print a citation in the text body without including it in the numbered bibliography, without modifying the .bib file directly?

A) Use the \nocite{} command for the entries you don't want in the bibliography
B) Add a 'nobib' keyword to the entries in the .bib file
C) Use a \defbibcheck{} command to filter out specific entries
D) Use the bibentry package instead of biblatex

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option A is incorrect because \nocite{} adds entries to the bibliography without citing them in the text, which is the opposite of what we want.

Option B involves modifying the .bib file directly, which the question specifically asks to avoid.

Option C is correct. The \defbibcheck{} command allows you to create a custom filter that can exclude specific entries from the bibliography based on various criteria, such as the entry key, without modifying the .bib file.

Option D is incorrect because the question specifically mentions using biblatex, and bibentry is a separate package that doesn't provide the same level of flexibility for this task.

The correct solution involves using \defbibcheck{} to create a custom filter, which can exclude entries based on their citation key or other criteria, allowing you to cite them in the text while omitting them from the final bibliography without modifying the .bib file.

\#\#\# User: **Nautilus** use to have the label for the file system in it's tree as "**File System**". Recently that was changed to now show "**Computer**" in the tree to open the file system. Regardless of why this change was made, how do I change it back? 

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/EYxyY.jpg)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: As far as I know... to change this label you should edit the nautilus Source Code.

**NOTE:** *In this example I'm running Ubuntu 13\.04 with nautilus (Files) 3\.6\.3*

**1\)** Make sure you have enable the [Source code repository](https://askubuntu.com/questions/221899/how-to-download-source-code-with-apt-get)

* Open the Ubuntu Software Center and in the Menu Bar choose **Edit \-\> Software Sources**.   

Click to enable "Source code repository".

Just in case I use the **"Main Server"** to Download.

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/gW5mw.png)

**2\)** Open a Terminal and install the necessary packages.

* `sudo apt-get install build-essential`

**3\)** Install build dependencies

* `sudo apt-get build-dep nautilus`

**4\)** Create a folder to download the source code.

* `mkdir ~/Downloads/src`
* `cd ~/Downloads/src`

**5\)** Download the source code.

* `apt-get source nautilus`

**6\)** Edit the file "nautilus\-places\-sidebar.c" 

Search for the line **3261** to edit.

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ZUKkC.png)

Replace "Computer" for "File System".

To edit:

* `gedit nautilus-3.6.3/src/nautilus-places-sidebar.c`

**BEFORE:**

> sidebar\-\>hostname \= g\_strdup (\_("Computer"));

**AFTER:**

> sidebar\-\>hostname \= g\_strdup (\_("File System"));

In one command would be:

* `sed -i '3261s/Computer/File\ System/' ~/Downloads/src/nautilus-3.6.3/src/nautilus-places-sidebar.c`

**7\)** Go to the "nautilus\-3\.6\.3" folder to build the deb packages.

* `cd nautilus-3.6.3/`
* `dpkg-buildpackage -rfakeroot -uc -b`

**8\)** Now you can install the deb packages.

* `cd ..`
* `sudo dpkg -i *deb`

**9\)** Finally you can logout and Login to see the changes.

**BEFORE:**

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/SYcOA.png)

**AFTER:**

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/pMyQc.png)

Hope it helps.

B) nautilus-places-sidebar.c, line 3261

Explanation: The correct file to modify is nautilus-places-sidebar.c, and the specific line that needs to be edited is 3261. This line contains the code that sets the label for the root of the file system in the Nautilus sidebar. The other options are incorrect as they refer to non-existent or irrelevant files and line numbers. 

To make this change, one would need to download the Nautilus source code, locate the specified file and line, change "Computer" to "File System" in the g_strdup function call, then rebuild and reinstall Nautilus. This process requires advanced knowledge of software compilation and system administration, which is why changing this label is not a simple user-accessible setting.

\#\#\# User: I know that you're generally told to align binary operators to the right of a relation symbol like this (using `{align*}`):

```
\begin{align*}
x={}&a+b+c\\
    &+d+e+f
\end{align*}

```

But would it look better (though be more error prone) to do something like this to get the \+ exactly flush with the a?

```
\begin{align*}
x={}&a+b+c\\
    &{+}\: d+e+f
\end{align*}

```

(That is, use braces to turn the \+ into an ordinary symbol and add the medium space between the \+ and the d by hand.)

Edit: I'm trying to do exactly what's said in rule 3\.3\.5b, "Break at conjunctions and align to the right of the first verb", on page 46 of *Mathematics into Type* (updated edition, 1999\).

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: First I want to summarize and discuss the variants.

```
\begin{align*}
x={}&a+b+c\\
    &+d+e+f
\end{align*}

```

> ![Unaligned](https://i.stack.imgur.com/6qGMX.png)

TeX adds space around binary operators in display and text style, thus the `+` is moved to the right and destroys the alignment.

The variant of cmhughes aligns the `+` signs. Because the horizontal space matters only, the example uses `\hphantom`:

```
\begin{align*}
x={}&a+b+c\\
    &\hphantom{a}+d+e+f
\end{align*}

```

> ![Alignment on plus signs](https://i.stack.imgur.com/gQujK.png)

The alignment on the first binary operator on the right side of the equation is a little arbitrary. Also `a` could be a huge summand moving the second line far to the right margin.

I agree with MSC that suppressing the white space before the plus sign makes sense.
He removes the property of a binary operator of the plus sign and manually adds the space for the following operand:

```
\begin{align*}
x={}&a+b+c\\  
    &{+}\: d+e+f
\end{align*}

```

> ![Alignment on the right side](https://i.stack.imgur.com/CNRZ4.png)

It can also be implemented the other way round by removing the space in front of the
binary operator:

```
\begin{align*}
x={}&a+b+c\\
    &\mskip-\medmuskip+ d+e+f
\end{align*}

```

This can also be implemented as macro:

```
\newcommand*{\leftbin}{%
  \nonscript\mskip-\medmuskip
  \mathbin
}

\begin{align*}
x={}&a+b+c\\
    &\leftbin+d+e+f
\end{align*}

```

It can also be used as `\leftbin{+}`. The space is only added in text and display math styles. Therefore `\nonscript` is used (see comment of egreg).
`\mathbin` ensures that the next math atom or sub formula is treated as binary operator.

\#\#\# User: I've looked at about every article/question on this issue that I've been able to find, but no luck \-\- thanks in advance for your help:

In my "This Workbook," I have the following:

```
Option Explicit

Public Sub Workbook_Open()
Application.OnKey "+^%{+}", "Insert_Columns"
End Sub

```

In a Module, I have the following:

```
Sub Insert_Columns()

Dim num As String

num = InputBox("How many columns do you want to insert?")

If num <> "" Then
    If num > 0 Then ActiveCell.Offset(0, 1).Resize(1, num).EntireColumn.Insert
End If

End Sub

```

For some reason, the shortcut is not working. I've tried many variations of this, but does anyone have an idea why the shortcut would not be working? The macro runs great if I click "Run" manually.

Thank you!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: When you use `for x in y:` x stores the variable itself, so you can check with an `if` the current object is equal to the one that's calling

The following sample have that behaviour

```
guest = ['Rambam', 'Rambo', 'Hulk']
for i in guest:
    newList = []
    for j in guest:
        if j != i:
            newList.append(j)

    print(newList)

```

`newList` will store all the guests *except* the one in the iteration

46.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided code sample:

Question: Consider the following Python code:

```python
guests = ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie', 'David']
result = []
for i in guests:
    newList = []
    for j in guests:
        if j != i:
            newList.append(j)
    result.append(newList)

print(result)
```

What will be the output of this code?

A) [['Bob', 'Charlie', 'David'], ['Alice', 'Charlie', 'David'], ['Alice', 'Bob', 'David'], ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie']]
B) [['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie'], ['Alice', 'Bob', 'David'], ['Alice', 'Charlie', 'David'], ['Bob', 'Charlie', 'David']]
C) [['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie', 'David'], ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie', 'David'], ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie', 'David'], ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie', 'David']]
D) [[], [], [], []]

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: 
This code creates a list of lists, where each inner list contains all guests except the one currently being iterated over in the outer loop. 

- For 'Alice', the inner list will be ['Bob', 'Charlie', 'David']
- For 'Bob', the inner list will be ['Alice', 'Charlie', 'David']
- For 'Charlie', the inner list will be ['Alice', 'Bob', 'David']
- For 'David', the inner list will be ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie']

These lists are then appended to the 'result' list in this order, producing the output shown in option A.

Option B is incorrect because it doesn't match the order of the original list. 
Option C is incorrect because it includes all guests in each inner list, which contradicts the `if j != i` condition. 
Option D is incorrect because it suggests empty lists, which would only happen if the condition was `if j == i`.

\#\#\# User: I am looking to prove the statement in the title, namely $\|\\mathbb{R} \- \\{r\\}\| \= c$ for every real number $r$. Obviously $\|\\mathbb{R}\| \= c$, so I was wondering if I was supposed to find a bijection between $\\mathbb{R}$ and $\\mathbb{R} \- \\{r\\}$. The function $f : \\mathbb{R} \- \\{r\\} \\to \\mathbb{R}$ where $f(x) \= x$ didn't look onto in this case, and I wasn't sure what else to try.

Thanks!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Consider the function $f$ such that
$$f(x) \= \\begin{cases}
1 \& \\text{if $x\=r$}\\\\
n\+1 \& \\text{ if $x\=n \\in \\mathbb{Z}^\+$}\\\\
x \& \\text{otherwise}
\\end{cases}$$

47.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given function:

Question: Consider the function f defined as:

f(x) = {
  1           if x = r
  n + 1       if x = n ∈ ℤ⁺
  x           otherwise
}

Where r is any real number. Which of the following statements is true about this function?

A) f is a bijection from ℝ to ℝ - {r}
B) f is a bijection from ℝ - {r} to ℝ
C) f is an injection but not a surjection from ℝ to ℝ
D) f is neither an injection nor a surjection from ℝ to ℝ

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
A) is incorrect because f is defined on all of ℝ, not just ℝ - {r}.
B) is correct. f maps ℝ - {r} onto ℝ in a one-to-one manner. Every real number is in the range of f, and each element in the domain maps to a unique element in the range.
C) is incorrect because f is actually surjective (onto) ℝ.
D) is incorrect because f is both injective and surjective when considered as a function from ℝ - {r} to ℝ.

The key insight is that this function "shifts" the positive integers up by 1, uses 1 as the image for r, and leaves all other numbers unchanged. This creates a bijection between ℝ - {r} and ℝ, proving that these sets have the same cardinality.

\#\#\# User: I have a directory with several subdirectories that all contain text files. In these text files, there is a certain word that occurs over and over again, and I want to replace every instance.

My Question \- How would I accomplish this from a linux commandline? I don't want to gedit every file and do a manual search/replace.

(For a bonus \- is there a way to do this in a case\-insensitive way?)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You could use `find` and `perl` (via `xargs`):

```
find /target/directory -type f | xargs perl -pi -e 's/stringtoreplace/replacement/g'

```

or if you are already in the right directory

```
find . -type f | xargs perl -pi -e 's/stringtoreplace/replacement/g'

```

and if you only want to replace in, say, html files:

```
find . -type f -name '*html' | xargs perl -pi -e 's/stringtoreplace/replacement/g'

```

You don't have to use perl of course, any tool that performs search and replace operations will do, and not doubt there are several available that are less resource hungry than starting perl (which is this case is a sledge\-hammer to crack a nut, but it is an example I've had stored for ages and I've no reason to find a more efficient version). My original source for the "trick" is <http://oreilly.com/pub/h/73>

You can use all the options in which\-ever tool you choose, so in this case the full power of Perl's regular expressions. The page linked to above has more examples, including how to search in a case in\-sensitive manner.

48.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You need to replace all occurrences of the word "legacy" with "modern" in all text files within a directory and its subdirectories on a Linux system. Which command would accomplish this task in a case-insensitive manner?

A) find . -type f | xargs sed -i 's/legacy/modern/g'
B) find . -type f | xargs perl -pi -e 's/legacy/modern/g'
C) find . -type f | xargs perl -pi -e 's/legacy/modern/gi'
D) find . -type f -name '*.txt' | xargs perl -pi -e 's/legacy/modern/g'

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
A) This command uses sed instead of perl and is not case-insensitive.
B) This command uses perl but is not case-insensitive.
C) This is the correct answer. It uses perl with the 'i' flag in the substitution command, making it case-insensitive. It will replace all occurrences of "legacy" with "modern" regardless of case in all files in the current directory and subdirectories.
D) This command limits the search to .txt files only and is not case-insensitive.

The correct command uses find to locate all files, pipes them to xargs which runs perl on each file. The perl command uses the -pi flags for in-place editing and printing, and the 's/legacy/modern/gi' performs a global (g) and case-insensitive (i) substitution.

Question: In the sentence "I grabbed him by the arm, hard, and herded him into the car, slammed the door" from Gone Girl by Gillian Flynn, why might the author have chosen to use the verb "herded" despite its typical association with moving groups?

A) The author made a grammatical error
B) To emphasize the forceful and controlling nature of the action
C) To suggest the character being moved was part of a larger group
D) To indicate the action was done slowly and carefully

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: While "herd" is typically used for moving groups of animals or people, the author likely chose this verb deliberately to evoke certain connotations. The use of "herded" in this context emphasizes the forceful, controlling nature of the action. It suggests the subject is treating the other person almost like an animal, pushing or guiding them against their will. This word choice adds to the intensity and potentially violent or coercive nature of the scene, even though only one person is being moved. The unusual application of "herded" to a single individual creates a vivid and unsettling image for the reader.

\#\#\# User: I have a feature class of points: `AL_CB_Parcel_Intersect`. This feature class is already in `GCS_WGS_1984`. I am trying to use `arcpy.AddGeometryAttributes` to create X, Y attributes, but I keep getting this error: 

> ExecuteError: ERROR 000622: Failed to execute (Add Geometry
>  Attributes). Parameters are not valid. ERROR 000628: Cannot set input
>  into parameter Coordinate\_System.

This works in ArcMap. 

What am I doing wrong in my script?

```
import arcpy
import os
parcels_dir = r"...\Processed"
stateabb = {'Alabama': 'AL',....}

coord_sys = "GCS_WGS_1984"

for k, v in stateabb.items():
if k == 'Alabama':
    print(k)
    parcel_gdb = "{}.gdb".format(k)
    parcel_cent = "{}_CB_Parcel_Intersect".format(v)
    parcel_path = os.path.join(parcels_dir, parcel_gdb)
    parcel_feat = os.path.join(parcel_path, parcel_cent)
    arcpy.env.workspace = parcel_path
    arcpy.AddGeometryAttributes_management(parcel_feat, "POINT_X_Y_Z_M", "", "", coord_sys)
    print("{} is done!".format(parcel_cent))

```

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Since your feature class is in `GCS_WGS_1984`, you don't need to specify any Coordinate System. Though, if you want to add `coord_sys` explicitly, you can use one of those:

* EPSG code as string e.g. "4326"
* EPSG code as integer e.g. 4326
* `SpatialReference` object

```
# as string
arcpy.AddGeometryAttributes_management(parcel_feat, "POINT_X_Y_Z_M", "", "", "4326")
#OR as integer
arcpy.AddGeometryAttributes_management(parcel_feat, "POINT_X_Y_Z_M", "", "", 4326)

#OR as SpatialReference object 
coord_sys = arcpy.SpatialReference(4326) # EPSG:4326 -> GCS_WGS_1984
arcpy.AddGeometryAttributes_management(parcel_feat, "POINT_X_Y_Z_M", "", "", coord_sys)

```

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: When using arcpy.AddGeometryAttributes_management() to add X, Y coordinates to a feature class already in GCS_WGS_1984, which of the following is NOT a valid way to specify the coordinate system parameter?

A) arcpy.AddGeometryAttributes_management(parcel_feat, "POINT_X_Y_Z_M", "", "", "4326")
B) arcpy.AddGeometryAttributes_management(parcel_feat, "POINT_X_Y_Z_M", "", "", 4326)
C) arcpy.AddGeometryAttributes_management(parcel_feat, "POINT_X_Y_Z_M", "", "", arcpy.SpatialReference(4326))
D) arcpy.AddGeometryAttributes_management(parcel_feat, "POINT_X_Y_Z_M", "", "", "GCS_WGS_1984")

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: Options A, B, and C are all valid ways to specify the coordinate system for a feature class in GCS_WGS_1984 when using arcpy.AddGeometryAttributes_management(). Option A uses the EPSG code as a string, option B uses the EPSG code as an integer, and option C uses a SpatialReference object. However, option D, which attempts to use the coordinate system name "GCS_WGS_1984" directly, is not a valid method for specifying the coordinate system in this function. The function expects either an EPSG code (as string or integer) or a SpatialReference object, not the coordinate system name.

I found only an API:

```
V1/directory/countries

```

How can I get cities for each country ?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There isn't a single template file for the product page, you can manipulate it by layout. 

See here the [doc](http://devdocs.magento.com/guides/v2.0/frontend-dev-guide/layouts/xml-instructions.html).

The main layout file is `magento/module-catalog/view/frontend/layout/catalog_product_view.xml`

In order to see the templates that forms the parts of your page, you can activate the **template hints** in:

> Store \-\> Configuration \-\> Advanced \-\> Developer \-\> Debug \> Enabled
>  Template Path Hints for Storefront \> Yes

52.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You are developing an e-commerce mobile app using Magento 2 and need to implement a shipping information form. Which of the following approaches would be most appropriate for retrieving a list of cities for each country?

A) Use the V1/directory/countries REST API endpoint to get countries, then implement a custom API endpoint to fetch cities for each country.

B) Modify the catalog_product_view.xml layout file to include city data alongside country information.

C) Enable template hints in the Magento admin panel to reveal hidden city data in the product page template.

D) There is no built-in Magento 2 API for retrieving cities by country. You would need to use a third-party service or create your own database of cities.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The question combines elements from both the API inquiry and the Magento 2 layout customization topics. The correct answer acknowledges that Magento 2 doesn't provide a built-in API for retrieving cities by country. While the V1/directory/countries endpoint exists for countries, there's no equivalent for cities.

Option A is incorrect because while the countries API exists, there's no mention of a built-in cities API.
Option B is incorrect because modifying the layout file won't provide city data; it's used for structuring the product page.
Option C is incorrect because enabling template hints is a debugging feature and won't reveal or provide city data.
Option D is correct because it accurately states the limitation of Magento 2's built-in APIs and suggests realistic alternatives for obtaining city data.

\#\#\# User: The way I explain it to myself is that a business rule is a requirement for a domain concept of an application.

One of the core tasks of my current app is to send notifications. Therefore I have a `Notification` entity, amongst others.

We are now facing the situation that I need to split a message in 2 parts and batch send them, because the API service provider has a message length limit.

From my point of view, this could be seen as a business rule (the requirement comes directly from the app owner), application logic (message is too long to send in one go with the current API implementation), or even a concern of the presentation layer (email bodies are created from templates).

How can I identify which layer a rule like this would belong to?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: A business rule is defined by business people and relates to business matters, regardless of the way these rules are implemented.

Unambiguous examples: 

* The change of the bank account of a beneficiary has to be approved by a different accountant than the one who registered the change (four eyes principle).
* A purchase agent can issue a purchase order up to $100K. Above this ceiling an approval by a manager is required.

These rules may be enforced purely with organisational means (a formal procedure that the employees gave to follow) or through automation (in the system). 

Ambiguous example:

* The title of the report shall be less than 140 characters
* The product description shall be no longer than 2000 characters

These two examples could be: 

* technical specifications of an arbitrary length, not justified by a business rule, but just because it is assumed to be sufficient;
* true business rules, if the business people decided that the information should not exceed these limits under any circumstances due to business reasons, for example in order to ensure concise answers and efficient processing (and avoid that the clerks have to read long novels instead of short statements).

To determine if it's a business rule, the easiest criteria would be to ask if this rule would make sense without the system (for example, if the information would be processes via paper forms). In your example it clearly isn't. 

A business rule is in general implemented in the business logic layer, because of its general nature (independent of the application).

53.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A software company is developing an application for a bank. Which of the following scenarios would most likely be considered a true business rule that should be implemented in the business logic layer?

A) The system should split long messages into multiple parts when sending notifications due to API limitations.

B) Customer account numbers must be exactly 10 digits long for compatibility with the bank's legacy systems.

C) A loan approval for amounts over $500,000 requires authorization from two separate managers.

D) The bank's logo should be displayed in the top-left corner of every page in the web application.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A business rule is defined by business people and relates to business matters, regardless of how it's implemented. It should make sense even without the system in place.

Option A is not a business rule, but rather a technical constraint due to API limitations.

Option B could be either a technical specification or a business rule, depending on whether it's an arbitrary technical decision or a business-driven requirement. More context would be needed to determine this definitively.

Option C is clearly a business rule. It's a policy set by the bank for risk management purposes and would apply even in a non-computerized system. It relates directly to the bank's operations and is independent of any technical implementation.

Option D is a user interface design decision, not a business rule.

The correct answer, C, would typically be implemented in the business logic layer due to its general nature and independence from specific application details.

\#\#\# User: 
> "I know," Matilda said. "I've tried quite a few times but mine are never any good."  
> 
> "You have, have you?" Miss Honey said, more startled than ever.  
> 
> "Well Matilda, I would very much like to hear one of these *limericks you say you have written*. Could you try to remember one for us?" (from the novel Matilda)

I know that this sentence is relative clauses:

> limericks you say you have written

Is this right sentence?

> limericks (which) you have written (which) you say.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This is a great question, and one of the reasons why speaking really good English is very complex and nuanced. Let's look at them one at a time:

"All water on Earth..." could have been 'All the water on the Earth' and no one would have batted an eye. But the first sounds more awesome... more like the announcer was really impressed.

"Not all water" this cannot have a definite article (the) because there is nothing definite about it. It is not speaking of water anywhere in particular, but water in general.

"All the water on Earth..." could have been 'all the water on the Earth" but not really 'all water on Earth'... since it is talking about the water that exists right now on Earth, a definite amount.

"The source of all water..." cannot be 'the source of all the water..." since it is not a definite kind of water, it is not located in space. You could say, "The source of all the water..." but you would have to be locating it in space, as in, "The source of all the water in our swimming pool is the Colorado River. We had it shipped in specially." (Don't try that at home.)

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following sentences uses articles correctly when discussing water on Earth?

A) All the water on Earth originated from comets and asteroids.
B) Not all the water on Earth is suitable for drinking.
C) The source of all the water on Earth is still debated by scientists.
D) All water on the Earth is part of the hydrologic cycle.

Correct Answer: A

Explanations:

A) Correct. "All the water on Earth" is appropriate when referring to a definite amount of water in a specific location (Earth).

B) Incorrect. "Not all water on Earth" would be correct, as it's referring to water in general, not a specific amount.

C) Incorrect. "The source of all water on Earth" would be correct, as it's not referring to a definite kind of water or specific location.

D) Incorrect. "All water on Earth" (without "the") would be more appropriate for a general, impressive statement about water.

\#\#\# User: Assume that a far star sends light toward a receiver. If we move this antenna such that it accelerate first for a moment, and then it moves with constant speed, we can see that the frequency of the received light will be shifted instantly in antenna's frame(toward blue or red, doesn't matter). The question is, in antenna's frame after acceleration, (which is indeed inertia) how can the frequency of the light still be shifted? After all, the light transmitter is far like 100 light years away, so when antenna moves, in antenna's frame we would expect some kind of delay to see a movement for the the far star (transmitter) and ofcourse the Doppler shift effect (antenna is at the rest in its frame, so the only reason for receiving doppler shifted frequency would be the movement of transmitter itself in this frame). But there is no such delay in formulas at least. 

If you don't get what i am trying to say note that in every frame, Doppler shift happens because of transmitter movements (every frame consider itself at the rest!). If transmitter starts its movement while it's 100 light years away, we will see transmitter movement and Doppler shift effect 100 years later. However, when antenna moves, there is no such delay which is very strange. It is as if transmitter doesn't move, but frequency has been changed out of thin air. 

I understand that in accelerated systems laws of physics changes, metric is different and etc. However, even by knowing accelerated frames metrics (like Rindler and such), i can't show that there is indeed a solution for this problem. Because after all, in reality antenna will recieve Doppler shifted light even after it maintains its speed and becomes inertia

I won't accept an answer without math even though i might upvote one. Everybody can say that accelerated systems are different, i need a thorough solution.

Update: you can generalize this question to every effects in SR, like Lorentz contraction between two points in a far away space. 

Update 2: Thanks to the help of all users, i am convinced that in accelerated frames there is nothing wrong with none local effects, for example if i rotate my head, i will see movement of stars immediately, hence @ThePhoton 's answer is acceptable for me now.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> The question is, in antenna's frame after acceleration, (which is indeed inertia) how can the frequency of the light still be shifted?

The light frequency was always shifted in this frame. (i.e. the frequency was always different in this frame than in the frame where the receiver is intially not moving)

You have two inertial frames, we can call them "A" and "B". Initially the receiver is at rest in frame A, and then it accelerates until it is at rest in frame B. But frame B wasn't created by this action. Frame B always existed. The only difference is that initially the receiver is at rest in frame A, so it measures the source frequency in frame A. Later the receiver is at rest in frame B, so it measures the source frequency in frame B.

But the frequency of the light in the frame B never changed, so there's no reason to worry about how it could have changed instantaneously.

55.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: An antenna initially at rest relative to a distant star suddenly accelerates to a constant velocity v away from the star. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the frequency of light received by the antenna after it reaches its constant velocity?

A) The frequency shift occurs gradually over time as information about the antenna's motion propagates to the star.

B) The frequency remains unchanged in the antenna's new rest frame, as the star has not moved relative to this frame.

C) The frequency shift occurs instantaneously in the antenna's new rest frame, despite the star being light-years away.

D) The frequency shift only occurs during the acceleration phase and disappears once the antenna reaches constant velocity.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The frequency shift occurs instantaneously in the antenna's new rest frame. This is because the new inertial frame (where the antenna is at rest after acceleration) always existed, and in this frame, the light frequency was always different from the original frame. The antenna's acceleration merely caused it to transition from one existing inertial frame to another. There's no need for information to propagate to the star or for the star to "move" in the new frame. The frequency shift is a consequence of the change in reference frames, not a physical change in the light itself that needs to propagate. This counterintuitive result highlights the relativity of simultaneity and the non-local nature of reference frame transformations in special relativity.

\#\#\# User: This is the problem:

> Does there exist positive integer $d$ ( which is not a perfect square ) such that the length of the least period in the simple continued fraction of $\\sqrt{d}$ is $3$?

Consider the following theorem

> **Theorem :** If the positive integer $d$ is not a perfect square, the simple continued fraction of $\\sqrt{d}$ has the form $\\sqrt{d} \= \[a\_0;\\overline{a\_1,a\_2,\\cdots,a\_{r\-1},2a\_o}]$ with $a\_o \= \\lfloor d \\rfloor$. Here $r$ denotes the length of the least period in the expansion of $\\sqrt{d}$. Where $\\lfloor x \\rfloor$ denotes the greatest integer function/ floor function of $x$.

We want to solve for non\-square $d$ where$\\sqrt{d} \= \[a\_0;\\overline{a\_1,a\_2,2a\_o}]$, and $a\_o \= \\lfloor d \\rfloor$. Since $d$ is a positive integer, $a\_o \= \\lfloor d \\rfloor \\ge 1$, and $a\_1 , a\_2$ are positive integers by definition. Please note that the converse of the above theorem is not true, for example, consider $\[1;\\overline{1,1,2}] \= \\sqrt{10}/2$ and $\[0;\\overline{1,1,0}] \= \\sqrt{2}/2$. I calculated first few continued fractions for $\\sqrt{d}$, $$\\begin{array}{c\|c\|c} \\sqrt{d} \& \\text{Continued fraction} \& r\\\\ \\hline
√2 \& \[1;\\bar{2}] \& 1 \\\\
√3 \& \[1;\\overline{1,2}] \& 2 \\\\
√5 \& \[2;\\bar{4}] \& 1\\\\
√6 \& \[2;\\overline{2,4}] \& 2\\\\
√7 \& \[2;\\overline{1,1,1,4}] \& 4\\\\
√8 \& \[2;\\overline{1,4}] \& 2\\\\
√10 \& \[3;\\bar{6}] \& 1\\\\
√11 \& \[3;\\overline{3,6}] \& 2\\\\
√12 \& \[3;\\overline{2,6}] \& 2\\\\
√13 \& \[3;\\overline{1,1,1,1,6}] \& 5\\\\
√14 \& \[3;\\overline{1,2,1,6}] \& 4\\\\
√15 \& \[3;\\overline{1,6}] \& 2\\\\
√17 \& \[4;\\bar{8}] \& 1\\\\
√18 \& \[4;\\overline{4,8}] \& 2\\\\
√19 \& \[4;\\overline{2,1,3,1,2,8}] \& 6 \\\\
√20 \& \[4;\\overline{2,8}] \& 2\\\\
√21 \& \[4;\\overline{1,1,2,1,1,8}] \& 6\\\\
√22 \& \[4;\\overline{1,2,4,2,1,8}] \& 6\\\\
√23 \& \[4;\\overline{1,3,1,8}] \& 4\\\\
√24 \& \[4;\\overline{1,8}] \& 2\\\\ \\end{array}$$

As we can see for $1\< d \\le 24, r \\ne 3$. Also, on a side note, observe that there does not exist two consecutive intergers $d$ and $d\+1$ such that both $\\sqrt{d}$ and $\\sqrt{d\+1}$ have $r\=1$, moreover there are infinitely $\\sqrt{d}$ such that the length of there least period is $1$ or $2$, $\\sqrt{n^2\+1} \= \[n;\\overline{2n}]$, $\\sqrt{n^2\+2} \= \[n;\\overline{n,2n}]$ and
$\\sqrt{n^2\-1} \= \[n\-1;\\overline{1,2(n\-1\)}]$ , where $n \\in \\mathbb{N}$ .Even for $r\=4$, we have $\\sqrt{n^2\-2} \= \[n\-1; \\overline{1,n\-2,1,2(n\-1\)}]$, $n\>2$. Now i have a hunch that no such $d$ exists for which $\\sqrt{d}$ have $r\=3$. Any hints on how to prove this ? In general does there exist a number $m$ such that $r\\ne m $ for any $\\sqrt{d}$ ?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes there are infinitely many. And it is not difficult to find them.

We seek continued fractions of the form

$\\sqrt{N}\=\[a,\\overline{b,c,2a}]$

First off, add $a$ to get a "pure" periodic expression. We shall call the quadratic surd $x$:

$x\=a\+\\sqrt{N}\=\[\\overline{2a,b,c}]$

We may then render

$x\=2a\+\\dfrac{1}{b\+\\dfrac{1}{c\+\\dfrac{1}{x}}}$

and upon clearing fractions

$(bc\+1\)x^2\+(b\-c\-2a(bc\+1\))x\-(2ab\+1\)\=0$

Now comes the sneaky part. If the above quadratic equation over the integers is to have a root $a\+\\sqrt{N}$, its other root must be $a\-\\sqrt{N}$ forcing the linear coefficient to be exactly $\-2a$ times the quadratic one! Thereby $b\=c$ above and the quadratic equation simplifies to:

$(b^2\+1\)x^2\-2a(b^2\+1\)x\-(2ab\+1\)\=0$

This gives an integer radicand whenever $2ab\+1$ is a multiple of $b^2\+1$, in which cases the common factor of $b^2\+1$ may be cancelled from the quadratic equation leaving the equation monic.

Suppose, for example, we drop in $b\=2$. Then $2ab\+1$ is to be a multiple of $5$ and $a$ can be any whole number one greater than a multiple of $5$. Putting $a\=1$ results in the "trivial" solution $\\sqrt{2}\=\[1,\\overline{2}]$, as the period is reduced from three to one due to $b\=c\=2a$. But this equality is avoided for larger eligible values of $a$ and we get a series of period $3$ solutions. In all cases $N$ is one fourth the discriminant of the monic polynomial obtained after cancelling out the $b^2\+1$ factor:

$a\=6\\to \\sqrt{41}\=\[6,\\overline{2,2,12}]$

$a\=11\\to \\sqrt{130}\=\[11,\\overline{2,2,22}]$

$a\=5k\+1\\to \\sqrt{25k^2\+14k\+2}\=\[5k\+1,\\overline{2,2,10k\+2}]$

There are more families of solutions like this with other values of $b$. Just put in an even positive value for $b$ (why even?) and turn the crank. You must put $a\>b/2$ to avoid the collapse we saw above with $\\sqrt{2}$.

---

So much for a repeat petiod of $3$, what about larger periods?

**Claim:** For any positive whole numbers $r$ there are at least an infinitude of $\\sqrt{N}$ continued fractions having repeat period $r$ where $N$ is a whole number, having the following form:

$\\sqrt{N}\=\[kP\_r\+1;\\overline{2,2,...,2,2(kP\_r\+1\)}]$

$P\_r$ is a Pell number defined by $P\_0\=0,P\_1\=P\_{\-1}\=1,P\_r\=2P\_{r\-1}\+P\_{r\-2}\\text{ for } r\\ge 2$, and $k$ is a whole number $\\ge 0$ for $r\=1$, $\\ge 1$ otherwise. The number of $2$ digits before the final entries is $r\-1$.

The proof bears some similarities to calculating the general solution for $r\=3$ above. First add $kP\_r\+1$ to the expression to make a purely periodic fraction:

$x\=kP\_r\+1\+\\sqrt{N}\=\[\\overline{2(kP\_r\+1\),2,2,...,2}]$

Then

$x\=2(kP\_r\+1\)\+\\dfrac{1}{\[2,2,...,2,x]}$

By mathematical induction on $r$ and using the recursive relation defined for Pell numbers in the claim it is true that

$\[2,2,...,2,x]\=\\dfrac{P\_rx\+P\_{r\-1}}{P\_{r\-1}x\+P\_{r\-2}}$

with $r\-1$ digits of $2$ in the block. When this is substituted into the previous equation the following is obtained:

$x\=2(kP\_r\+1\)\+\\dfrac{P\_{r\-1}x\+P\_{r\-2}}{P\_rx\+P\_{r\-1}}$

$x\=\\dfrac{(2(kP\_r\+1\)P\_r\+P\_{r\-1})x\+2(kP\_r\+1\)P\_{r\-1}\+P\_{r\-2}}{P\_rx\+P\_{r\-1}}$

$(P\_r)x^2\-2(kP\_r\+1\)P\_rx\-(2(kP\_r\+1\)P\_{r\-1}\+P\_{r\-2})\=0$

Upon completing the square and back\-substituting $\\sqrt{N}\=x\-(P\_rk\+1\)$ we obtain:

$N\=\\dfrac{(kP\_r\+1\)^2P\_r\+2(kP\_r\+1\)P\_{r\-1}\+P\_{r\-2}}{P\_r}$

Using the Pell number recursion to eliminate $P\_{r\-2}$:

$N\=\\dfrac{(kP\_r\+1\)^2P\_r\+2(kP\_r)P\_{r\-1}\+P\_r}{P\_r}\=(kP\_r\+1\)^2\+2kP\_{r\-1}\+1$

thereby identifying $N$ as a whole number. For a full fundamental period $\\ge 2$ the terminal element must not match the other elements, so in that case $k\\ge 1$. Else (meaning a period of just $1$), $k$ may be any whole number, $k\\ge 0$.

56.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Consider the continued fraction expansion of √N where N is a positive integer that is not a perfect square. Which of the following statements is true?

A) It is impossible for the length of the least period in the simple continued fraction of √N to be 3.

B) There are infinitely many values of N for which the length of the least period in the simple continued fraction of √N is 3.

C) The length of the least period in the simple continued fraction of √N can never be an odd number greater than 1.

D) For any positive integer r, there are only finitely many values of N for which the length of the least period in the simple continued fraction of √N is r.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because the documentation provides a method to generate infinitely many examples where the period length is 3.
B is correct as the documentation shows how to construct infinitely many such numbers, e.g. √41 = [6;2,2,12], √130 = [11;2,2,22], and generally √(25k^2+14k+2) = [5k+1;2,2,10k+2] for positive integers k.
C is false because the documentation provides examples of odd period lengths, including 3 and 5.
D is incorrect because the documentation proves that for any positive integer r, there are infinitely many N for which √N has a continued fraction expansion with period length r.

57.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A user is experiencing connectivity issues on their Ubuntu 18.04 system. They can connect to Google, but not to other websites. Based on the network configuration output provided, what is the most likely cause of this issue?

A) The system's DNS settings are incorrect
B) The wireless adapter is malfunctioning
C) The system lacks an IPv4 address assignment
D) The router is blocking access to non-Google websites

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The output of the ifconfig command shows that the wireless interface (wlp0s20f3) only has IPv6 addresses assigned, but no IPv4 address. This explains why the user can reach Google (which supports IPv6) but not other websites or even ping their router's IPv4 address. The lack of output from the "ip route show" command further confirms the absence of IPv4 routing. Disabling IPv6 or properly configuring IPv4 addressing would likely resolve the issue.

\#\#\# User: I have many double entries in Launchpad.![see screenshot](https://i.stack.imgur.com/0HEuZ.png) (Address Book, DVD Player, Image Capture). Any idea why and how to fix it?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Launchpad looks for applications in at least two different locations: the Applications folder in your Home directory, and the "root" Applications folder sitting in "Macintosh HD." If it sees an application in more than one place, it puts an icon on the Launchpad for each place it's in. (Try using Spotlight to see if you have more than one Address Book!)

Moving the extraneous apps out of \~/Applications should put them out of Launchpad's sight (at least, as of the next reboot).

58.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: You notice multiple icons for the same applications appearing in your Mac's Launchpad. What is the most likely cause of this issue and how can it be resolved?

A) The applications are corrupted and need to be reinstalled. To fix this, uninstall and reinstall the affected applications.

B) Launchpad's database is corrupted. To fix this, reset Launchpad by running a terminal command.

C) The same applications exist in both the user's Home directory Applications folder and the root Applications folder. To fix this, move the duplicate applications out of the Home directory's Applications folder.

D) The Mac's display settings are causing visual glitches. To fix this, adjust the screen resolution in System Preferences.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The question tests understanding of how Launchpad functions on a Mac. According to the documentation, Launchpad searches for applications in multiple locations, including the user's Home directory Applications folder (~\Applications) and the root Applications folder. If an application exists in both locations, Launchpad will display multiple icons for it. The correct solution is to move the duplicate applications out of the Home directory's Applications folder, leaving only one instance in the root Applications folder. This will cause Launchpad to display only one icon per application after a system reboot.

\#\#\# User: I'm just finishing up adding outlets to the front and back of my house. I have it arranged such that a new line runs from the panel to a junction box, where it T's off to feed the new outlets. I understand that I need GFCI protection on this circuit, but I'm not really familiar with the ground fault application. If I were to add a GFCI outlet at some point between the panel and the junction box, would the two branches coming out of the junction box both be GFCI protected?[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/9dOri.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/9dOri.png)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes, you can. Electrically that's no different than having a series of outlets on a single run after a GFCI. Everything is wired in parallel regardless.

59.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An electrician is installing a new circuit with multiple outlets on the exterior of a house. The circuit originates from the main panel, goes through a junction box, and then splits to feed outlets on the front and back of the house. If the electrician installs a GFCI outlet between the panel and the junction box, which of the following statements is correct?

A) Only the outlets on one branch after the junction box will be GFCI protected
B) The GFCI outlet will protect itself, but no other outlets on the circuit
C) All outlets on both branches after the junction box will be GFCI protected
D) The GFCI outlet will interfere with the proper functioning of the circuit and should not be installed in this configuration

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. When a GFCI outlet is installed upstream of a junction box, it provides GFCI protection to all downstream outlets, regardless of how the circuit branches after the GFCI. This is because all outlets are wired in parallel, and the GFCI protection extends to all devices on the load side of the GFCI outlet. 

Answer A is incorrect because GFCI protection doesn't discriminate between branches after a junction box. 
Answer B is false because GFCI outlets protect all downstream devices, not just themselves. 
Answer D is incorrect because this is a valid and common configuration for GFCI protection in outdoor circuits.
